instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
usb c meter 20v0, 0.03a
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 20v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13.6v, is low
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 13.6v
voltage at L7030 11v
i replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, but no change <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is low

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13.6v, is low"
Why do you think that???

"<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 20v
-----------
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 13.6v""
Really impossible, believe me; check schematic.

Plerase, post accurate information, if you need help.

Any voltage at L7670/90?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
I thought <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> need not be 20v, but I was wrong.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13.05v
L7670 3.3V
L7690 3.3V
I was wrong in the diagnostic from the beginning.

The board get into S0 state, but no Vcore. 
The CPU get hot and the fan spin after while.

??????There been water damage on next backlight circuit, I know it make a risk for the CPU... Also the water damage was everywhere...


????

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
"L7670 3.3V"
Don't you mean 5V there???

Do you get voltage at L7370 and L7210/20?

Water close to backlight circuit is the worst repair scenario.
You can have now a dead CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
The board is consuming 20v/0.14a
L7670 5.1V
L7370 1.04V
L7210 0V
L7220 0V

There was no a lot of corrosion on the backlight circuit, I hope CPU fine. I send a photo of this area

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage
threads.message:
Try known good BIOS, just in case.
Liquid could affect internal copper layers, where are many data signal lines.
Test the board alone on the desk, no device connected.
Just check for voltage at L7210/20.
